title: Question 120

children: An 82-year-old man is evaluated after having fallen while walking to his bedroom in the dark. He reports no preceding lightheadedness, loss of consciousness, current symptoms, or previous falls.

On physical examination, orthostatic vital signs are normal. Gait is normal. Position and vibration sensation are intact. Corrected vision is 20/20. The Timed Up and Go test is completed in 10 seconds.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
An evaluation for home safety is always an appropriate consideration for patients who have fallen, because hazards are found in two thirds of homes.

Patients with falls or fear of falling should be screened with the Timed Up and Go test; patients who take more than 12 seconds to complete these tasks are considered high risk for subsequent falling and should be further evaluated.
A home safety evaluation (
Option A

) is most appropriate for this patient. He fell in his home and has no indication of gait abnormality, visual deficit, or weakness. His walking to the bedroom in the dark and resulting mechanical stumble may have caused the fall. An evaluation for home safety is always an appropriate consideration for patients who have fallen, because hazards are found in two thirds of homes. It would be important to know if he has night lights in each room, because lack of proper lighting would contribute to his risk for falls. Installing night lights in each room is a simple and inexpensive fall prevention strategy. Other potential modifiable home safety issues related to falls include the presence of rugs, thresholds between rooms, general clutter, uneven lighting, and unsafe or absent handrails.

Patients with falls or fear of falling should be screened with the Timed Up and Go test, during which the patient is asked to arise from a chair, walk 10 feet, turn around, and sit in the same chair. Patients who take more than 12 seconds to complete these tasks are considered high risk for subsequent falling and should be further evaluated. This patient's normal gait and Timed Up and Go test result indicate that he does not require further gait evaluation (
Option B

Patients with falls and identified weakness or gait abnormalities may benefit from formal gait retraining/strengthening programs individualized to address their deficits. A supervised exercise program (
Option C
) is probably unnecessary in this patient with a normal gait examination and Timed Up and Go test result.
Neither vitamin B
nor vitamin D supplementation is indicated (
Option D
). Severe and prolonged vitamin B

deficiency can result in subacute combined degeneration, which refers to a dysfunction of the corticospinal and dorsal sensory tracts of the spinal cord that manifests as spastic paresis with reduced vibration and position sense and ataxia. Patients are at risk for falling and may be especially prone to fall in the dark. However, this patient has normal position and vibratory sensation as well as a normal gait, and vitamin B

supplementation is not indicated. The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends against vitamin D supplementation to prevent falls in community-dwelling adults aged 65 years or older who are not known to have osteoporosis or vitamin D deficiency.

objective.__html: Manage fall risk in an elderly patient.

references: Phelan EA, Ritchey K. Fall prevention in community-dwelling older adults.
